data.title: Fix coffelint error causing Travis builds to fail
data.body:
Currently, running coffeelint produces this error and causes Travis builds to fail:

```
Running "coffeelint:src" (coffeelint) task
src/command-installer.coffee
  ✖  line 73  Line contains inconsistent indentation  Expected 2 got 0
✖ 1 error
Warning: Task "coffeelint:src" failed. Use --force to continue.
Error: Task "coffeelint:src" failed.
```

See clutchski/coffeelint#189 for more information on this problem and suggested approach, and for a different place in Atom where this approach is used see this:

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/ca39c106d6570b7e46129dd445dde3b9ba84cf9f/src/config.coffee#L984

cc @mnquintana @kevinsawicki for :eyes: and :thought_balloon: in case there's a better way to fix this.

data.title: [Windows] Pinned Atom icon disappears with every update.
data.body: Currently when Atom updates, the previously pinned icon on the taskbar vanishes and you have to pin it again manually.

data.title: 1.0.15.rpm fails to launch as root (kdesu) under KDE
data.body:
I run opensuse 13.2

```
 lsb_release -rd
    Description:    openSUSE 13.2 (Harlequin) (x86_64)
    Release:        13.2

uname -rm
    4.2.0-7.g2d05727-desktop x86_64
```

My DE is KDE

```
rpm -qa | egrep "kde|plasma"
    ...
    kdebase4-runtime-15.08.1-1.1.x86_64
    plasma5-desktop-5.4.90git~20150918T192035~954a1a9-20.1.x86_64
    ...
```

The session mgr is KDE's default, SDDM

```
sddm-0.99-21.1.x86_64
```

SDDM's PAM config is

```
/etc/pam.d/sddm
    auth     [success=done ignore=ignore default=bad] pam_selinux_permit.so
    auth        substack      password-auth
    -auth        optional      pam_gnome_keyring.so
    -auth        optional      pam_mate_keyring.so
    auth        include       postlogin

    account     required      pam_nologin.so
    account     include       password-auth

    password    include       password-auth

    session     required      pam_selinux.so close
    session     required      pam_loginuid.so
    session     optional      pam_console.so
    -session    optional    pam_ck_connector.so
    session     required      pam_selinux.so open
    session     optional      pam_keyinit.so force revoke
    session     required      pam_namespace.so
    session     include       password-auth
    -session     optional      pam_gnome_keyring.so auto_start
    -session     optional      pam_mate_keyring.so auto_start
    session     include       postlogin
```

gnome-keyring-daemon is set to autostart in kdebase4

```
/home/pgnd/.config/autostart-scripts/gnome-keyring.sh
    #!/bin/sh
    /usr/bin/gnome-keyring-daemon --start --components=pkcs11,secrets,ssh,gpg
    export SSH_AUTH_SOCK
    export GPG_AGENT_INFO
```

After boot,

```
ps ax | grep keyring
    13716 ?        Sl     0:00 /usr/bin/gnome-keyring-daemon --start --components=pkcs11,secrets
```

I'm running Atom release 1.0.15.rpm

```
rpm -qa | grep -i ^atom
    atom-1.0.15-0.1.fc21.x86_64
```

It execs as 'my user'

```
which atom 
    /usr/bin/atom

whoami
    pgnd

/usr/bin/atom
(launches & functions ok)
```

But fails to launch under kdesu

```
kdesu /usr/bin/atom

tail -f /var/log/messages
    ...
    Sep 19 18:04:37 pgdesk su: The gnome keyring socket is not owned with the same credentials as the user login: /run/user/1000/keyring/control
    Sep 19 18:04:37 pgdesk su: gkr-pam: couldn't unlock the login keyring.
    Sep 19 18:04:37 pgdesk su: (to root) pgnd on pts/8
    Sep 19 18:04:37 pgdesk su: The gnome keyring socket is not owned with the same credentials as the user login: /run/user/1000/keyring/control
    Sep 19 18:04:37 pgdesk su: gkr-pam: couldn't unlock the login keyring.
    Sep 19 18:04:37 pgdesk su: (to root) pgnd on pts/8
```

Where

```
ls -al /run/user/1000/keyring/control
    srwxr-xr-x 1 pgnd users 0 Sep 19 17:50 /run/user/1000/keyring/control=
```

data.title: Create draft release with correct target branch
data.body:
This way, we won't accidentally tag the head of master when clicking 'Publish' for beta and stable releases.

/cc @nathansobo

data.title: atom.workspace.observeTextEditors will observe an edit multiple times if the editor is moved to another pane.
data.body:
Found this working on Nuclide:

Moving a TextEditor to another pane with pane.moveItemToPane() will cause atom.workspace.observeTextEditors to get fired with that editor a second time.

We've seen packages using observeTextEditors hit bugs when observeTextEditors is fired with the same editor multiple times. We should either enforce this invariant in moveItemToPane, or document that observeTextEditors does not guarantee exactly one call per editor.

data.title: Interface is blank on 3/4 of screen
data.body:
Just updated to 1.0.13 on OSX 10.10.5. When I open up atom through the command line(`atom`) or through the dock icon 3/4 of my screen is white: 

![screen shot 2015-09-18 at 10 29 36 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4634290/9964914/2e1b8d58-5df0-11e5-80df-d68122e063ca.png)

It looks like it is only happening if I have it at a certain size on my external monitor (thunderbolt display running @ 2560-by-1440). The window size in that screen shot is around 2400x1300

This also happens if I run it in safe mode from the command line (`atom --safe`)

It does fix itself if I resize the window

data.title: .atom/storage corruption messing up blue dot on dirty buffers
data.body:
I'm having a strange issue where sometimes Atom stops displaying the little blue dot in the tab bar for dirty buffers (unsaved modified files).

This has happened twice now since yesterday, and each time it was resolved by deleting my `.atom/storage` directory.

Any thoughts on first troubleshooting steps?

data.title: CustomEvent inheritance change breaks vim-mode in 1.12
data.body:
[This commit](https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/e3f9074f4a98f15a4436a79a2209e2fdece85dd4), added in 1.12 released a day ago, removes `originalEvent` from dispatched events. This breaks vim-mode's use of the same event for multiple different keys:

``` cson
  '1': 'vim-mode:repeat-prefix'
  '2': 'vim-mode:repeat-prefix'
  '3': 'vim-mode:repeat-prefix'
```

I've poked around at the new events from the vim-mode point of view, and without the `originalEvent`, there's no way to fix it other than to create tons of unique events, like in [this commit](https://github.com/atom/vim-mode/commit/d73e0916c51374c22c36fb4fd9931e7ded0b4c17), which is so bad I can't bring myself to make a PR out of it.

It seems like the breaking commit is attempting to keep the API the same, but the original event keys are part of the event prototype, not the event, so they're not copied. It looks like there's been [some work on that file](https://github.com/atom/atom/commits/master/src/command-registry.coffee) since the breaking commit, but nothing in the last day or two, so I'm hoping this isn't a duplicate.

For reference, the vim-mode code that's referencing the missing `originalEvent` is [here](https://github.com/atom/vim-mode/blob/master/lib/vim-state.coffee#L587-L588) and [here](https://github.com/atom/vim-mode/blob/master/lib/vim-state.coffee#L575-L576). And the break is pretty dramatic, making vim-mode more or less unusable.

data.title: Text rendering on OS X
data.body:
Text rendering on OS X could be improved, by using `text-rendering: optimizeLegibility;`
The issue is especially visible on a Retina display.
With `optimizeLegibility`, letter spacing is more homogeneous.

![Imgur](http://i.imgur.com/YbaKeLW.png)
`text-rendering: auto;`

![Imgur](http://i.imgur.com/v2JX6Gl.png)
`text-rendering: optimizeLegibility;`

data.title: :memo: Suggest branch name section in CONTRIBUTING
data.body:
# What
- Suggestion for writing `branch-name` section in `CONTRIBUTING.md`
- What I wrote is just for the first draft, and should be reviewed and improved
# Why
- With the more contributor is getting joined with this community, there are a bunch of branch name
  without any under coherence
# How
- I strongly believe that beginning with Github Username is easy to find and at the same time recognizable
- As for the latter part (topic categories and branch name style), I would like to hear more contributor's opinions

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'which' of undefined
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce below:]
1. Using vim mode, set up a function to allow you to use j j to exit insert mode to normal mode
   Here is that function:

init.coffee

``` coffee
atom.commands.add 'atom-text-editor', 'custom:wait-key-press', (e)->
  oe = e.originalEvent
  char = String.fromCharCode(oe.which)
  char = char.toLowerCase() unless oe.shift
  atom.workspace.getActivePaneItem().insertText(char)
```

keymap.cson

``` cson
'.editor.vim-mode.insert-mode':
  'j': 'custom:wait-key-press'

'.vim-mode.insert-mode:not(.mini)':
  'j j': 'vim-mode:activate-normal-mode'
```
1. Press the j key once.
### Notes
- I didn't write this function. I stole it from [here](https://github.com/atom/vim-mode/issues/334#issuecomment-110577371)
- It worked up til 1.0.11, but not for 1.0.12 or 1.0.13
- I may be missing that this was added natively to atom (key melodies, if you will) but I've looked at the release notes and don't see anything.

**Atom Version**: 1.0.13
**System**: Mac OS X 10.10.5
**Thrown From**: Atom Core
### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'which' of undefined

```
At /Users/cm022291/.dotfiles/atom/init.coffee:15

TypeError: Cannot read property 'which' of undefined
    at atom-text-editor.<anonymous> (/Users/cm022291/.dotfiles/atom/init.coffee:15:32)
    at CommandRegistry.module.exports.CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent (/opt/homebrew-cask/Caskroom/atom/1.0.10/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/command-registry.js:240:29)
    at /opt/homebrew-cask/Caskroom/atom/1.0.10/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/command-registry.js:3:61
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.dispatchCommandEvent (/opt/homebrew-cask/Caskroom/atom/1.0.10/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:524:16)
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent (/opt/homebrew-cask/Caskroom/atom/1.0.10/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:347:22)
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.terminatePendingState (/opt/homebrew-cask/Caskroom/atom/1.0.10/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:498:14)
```
### Commands

```
     -0:02.6.0 vim-mode:insert-after (atom-text-editor.editor.vim-mode.normal-mode.is-focused)
     -0:01.1.0 custom:wait-key-press (atom-text-editor.editor.vim-mode.is-focused.insert-mode)
```

data.title: Unable to install packages behind proxy
data.body:
I am behind a corporate proxy.

Since Atom version 1.0.12 (and 1.0.13), I am not able to install or update any atom package.
This problem is related to the already fixed issue https://github.com/atom/apm/issues/322

When I use Atom version 1.0.11, everything works as expected.

My `.apmrc`

```
http-proxy=http://xxx:8080
https-proxy=http://xxx:8080
strict-ssl=false
```

Manual installation of a package with `apm`

``` bash
> apm -v
apm  1.0.4
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.6
git 1.9.1

> apm install atom-material-ui
Installing atom-material-ui to /home/bjoernsen/.atom/packages 
gyp info it worked if it ends with ok
gyp info using node-gyp@2.0.2
gyp info using node@0.10.40 | linux | x64
gyp http GET https://atom.io/download/atom-shell/v0.30.6/node-v0.30.6.tar.gz
gyp http 500 https://atom.io/download/atom-shell/v0.30.6/node-v0.30.6.tar.gz
gyp WARN install got an error, rolling back install
gyp ERR! install error 
gyp ERR! stack Error: 500 response downloading https://atom.io/download/atom-shell/v0.30.6/node-v0.30.6.tar.gz
gyp ERR! stack     at Request.<anonymous> (/usr/share/atom/resources/app/apm/node_modules/npm/node_modules/node-gyp/lib/install.js:251:14)
```

data.title: Auto-update should not be compulsory
data.body:
##### Expected:

I open Atom, ready for another productive day of work.
##### Reality:

Atom uses all 60KB/s of my bandwidth to download an unneeded update and I can't get anything done for the next hour.
##### Possible Fixes:

Add a checkbox to Settings that allows those of us in low-bandwith situations to turn off auto-updating.

Thanks!

data.title: Can't rebuild package after updating to 1.0.13
data.body:
The 'red bug' appeared in the bottom right corner of the status bar after updating to 1.0.13, and led me to an UI where I could rebuild my package. Rebuilding kept failing with the following error message:

```
/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/apm/node_modules/npm/bin/node-gyp-bin/node-gyp: line 3: node: command not found

npm ERR! Darwin 14.5.0
npm ERR! argv "/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/apm/bin/node" "/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/apm/node_modules/npm/bin/npm-cli.js" "--globalconfig" "/Users/david/.atom/.apm/.apmrc" "--userconfig" "/Users/david/.atom/.apmrc" "rebuild" "--target=0.30.6" "--arch=x64"
npm ERR! node v0.10.40
npm ERR! npm  v2.13.3
npm ERR! file sh
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
npm ERR! errno ENOENT
npm ERR! syscall spawn
npm ERR! oniguruma@4.2.2 install: `node-gyp rebuild`
npm ERR! spawn ENOENT
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Failed at the oniguruma@4.2.2 install script 'node-gyp rebuild'.
npm ERR! This is most likely a problem with the oniguruma package,
npm ERR! not with npm itself.
npm ERR! Tell the author that this fails on your system:
npm ERR!     node-gyp rebuild
npm ERR! You can get their info via:
npm ERR!     npm owner ls oniguruma
npm ERR! There is likely additional logging output above.

npm ERR! Please include the following file with any support request:
npm ERR!     /Users/david/git/language-markdown/npm-debug.log
```

Eventually, after discussion in the #atom channel on Slack with @as-cii and @simurai, and after `apm rebuild`-ing numerous times via the command line, and after a re-install of Atom, rebuilding finally worked. So, my problem is fixed, but I suppose this isn't intended behavior.

The package that caused this was [language-markdown](http://atom.io/packages/language-markdown/).

`npm-debug.log` got unfortunately erased once the rebuild succeeded.

data.title: Opening larger txt file slows atom / upon opening freeze for period of time
data.body:
Hey,

I was just opening a larger text-file with atom editor on windows 7 and noticed the following reproducable behaviour:

Upon display of file atom editor freezed and did not respond to any actions.
After a period of time, 1-2 minutes, I was able to use the file.

The file had a size of 2.248kb - so we are not talking about a huge file.
This should in my humble opinion work smooth.

Also closing the file tab produced a short lag without responding to actions.

Regards,
Stefan

data.title: Is there a verbose backup function?
data.body:
Assume the following scenario, I modified a file with atom, saved it, closed atom. Suddenly I realize I was wrong, I want to restore the file. But there is not a backup file, and undo or ctrl+z does not work. 
So I must modify it manually.
So should add a verbose backup function?  It will backup it automatically when I modify the file. Of course, more disk space will be used.

data.title: Changing UI/Syntax theme colors 3 times reverts ALL settings to defaults
data.body: I just started using this today, running version 1.0.13 on Windows 10 64-bit. I was messing with the theme settings after I had my other settings (which plugins were enabled, editor settings, etc) configured. I changed the theme three times, then the UI became very screwed up. ![Weird UI](http://i.imgur.com/6xPhzMv.png) It stayed screwed up whenever I changed the theme again, so I tried closing and reopening Atom. Then I was greeted with the welcome screen which I got rid of, and all my tabs were gone. I checked my settings, and sure enough, they were back to the defaults.

data.title: Tab switching slow with files opened over SFTP connection
data.body:
Ubuntu 14.04 3.16.0-43-generic
Atom 1.0.11
No 3rd party packages

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open Ubuntu 'Files' (file browser)
2. Click Connect to Server
3. Enter details for SFTP server (mine is local connected to the same switch as my computer)
4. Open Atom
5. Click File > Open Folder
6. Browse to the open SFTP connection
7. Open folder containing multiple files containing at least 30 lines
8. Open at least two tabs
9. Switch between tabs

Expected results:
I see at least a 1 second delay when switching between two 20-50 line files. The delay is larger for bigger files. There is no noticeable delay when opening local files.

Not sure if this is an Atom issue, but I haven't seen the behavior with any other editor I commonly use (Vim, Sublime).

data.title: Cannot find module binary
data.body:
Hi,

I'm trying to upgrade from Atom 1.0.11 to 1.0.13 on Sabayon. I originally installed 1.0.11 from source code from the method outlined in `linux.md`. To upgrade to 1.0.13 I ran:

``` sh
git fetch -p
git checkout v1.0.13
script/build
sudo script/grunt install
```

from my clone of the Atom git repo. `script/build` gave this output:

``` sh
Node: v0.12.7
npm: v2.13.3
Installing build modules...
Installing apm...
Installing modules ✓
Deduping modules ✓
Running "download-electron" task

Fatal error: Cannot find module 'binary'
```

I had never seen this error before, even though I have used this upgrade technique before without error. 

Thanks for your time,
Brenton
